revision.text: {|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin | name=1MF10 | image=Mitsubishi 1MF10.jpg | caption=Mitsubishi 1MF10 }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type | type=Fighter aircraft | national origin=[[Japan]] | manufacturer=[[Mitsubishi|Mitsubishi Kokuki KK]] | designer=[[Jiro Horikoshi]] | first flight=March 1933 | introduced= | retired= | status=Prototype | primary user= | more users= | produced= | number built=2 | program cost= | unit cost= | developed from= | variants with their own articles= }} |} The '''Mitsubishi 1MF10''' or '''Mitsubishi Experimental ''7-Shi'' Carrier Fighter''' (七試艦上戦闘機) was a prototype Japanese monoplane single-seat carrier-based fighter aircraft of the 1930s. Two were built for the [[Imperial Japanese Navy]], but both were lost in crashes, with no production following. ==Design and development== In April 1932, the [[Imperial Japanese Navy]] issued a specification for a replacement for its current carrier-based fighter, the [[Nakajima A2N]], asking for designs from both [[Mitsubishi]] and [[Nakajima Aircraft Company|Nakajima]]. Unlike the [[biplane]] which was to be replaced, both competitors submitted [[monoplane]]s, with Nakajima offering a version of its [[Nakajima Army Type 91 Fighter|Type 91]] [[parasol-wing]] fighter, already in production for the [[Imperial Japanese Army Air Force|Japanese Army]]. Mitsubishi assigned design of its contestant to a team led by [[Jiro Horikoshi]], which created the first low-wing [[Cantilever#Aircraft|cantilever]] monoplane to be designed in Japan, the Mitsubishi 1MF10.Mikesh and Abe 1990, p. 170.Green and Swanborough 1994, p. 407. The 1MF10 was of all-metal construction, with a [[monocoque]] [[duralumin]] [[fuselage]], with duralumin wing structure covered in fabric, with the pilot accommodated in an open cockpit. The aircraft was powered by a [[Mitsubishi A4]] two-row 14-cylinder [[radial engine]] driving a two-bladed propeller. It had a fixed [[conventional landing gear|tailwheel undercarriage]]. The first prototype 1MF10, with the Navy designation Experimental ''7-shi'' Carrier Fighter{{#tag:ref|In the Japanese Navy designation system, specifications were given a ''Shi'' number based on the year of the Emperor's reign it was issued. In this case 7-''Shi'' stood for 1932, the 7th year of the [[Shōwa period|Shōwa era]].Mikesh and Abe 1990, pp. 2, 286.|group=lower-alpha}} made its maiden flight in March 1933. It was destroyed in July 1933 when its tail broke up during diving tests, although the pilot escaped by parachute. The second prototype had a revised undercarriage, with the main wheels and undercarriage legs faired into streamlined spats. It was also destroyed in a crash, when it could not be recovered from a flat [[Spin (flight)|spin]] in June 1934. Although the design was advanced, it was rejected by the Japanese Navy, having poor handling and not meeting the performance requirements of the specification. It did form the basis of more advanced designs, however, with Horikoshi using elements of it such as the box-[[Spar (aviation)|spar]] in the later successful [[Mitsubishi A5M]] fighter of similar layout.Mikesh and Abe 1990, pp. 170–171. ==Specifications== {{Aircraft specs |ref=Japanese Aircraft 1910–1941Mikesh and Abe 1990, p. 171. |prime units?=met |genhide= |crew=1 |capacity= |length m=6.92
